title: What is the meaning of the song 'White Rabbit' by Jefferson Airplane? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is what I found on WikiPedia about White Rabbit and its composer Grace Slick. "White Rabbit " is one of Grace Slick's earliest songs, written during either late 1965 or early 1966. It utilizes imagery found in the fantasy works of Lewis Carroll: 1865's Alice's Adventures in Wonderland and its 1871 sequel Through the Looking-Glass, such as changing size after taking pills or drinking an unknown liquid. Slick had stated the composition was intended to be a slap to parents who would read their children such novels, and then wonder why their children would later use drugs.  Characters Slick referenced include Alice, the hookah-smoking caterpillar, the White Knight, the Red Queen, and the Dormouse. Although for Slick, White Rabbit "is about following your curiosity. The White Rabbit is your curiosity", For her and others in the 1960s, drugs were a part of mind-expanding and social experimentation. With its enigmatic lyrics, "White Rabbit" became one of the first songs to sneak drug references past censors on the radio. Even Marty Balin, Slick's eventual rival in Jefferson Airplane, regarded the song as a "masterpiece". In interviews, Slick has related that Alice in Wonderland was often read to her as a child, and remained a vivid memory well into her adulthood. In an interview with The Wall Street Journal Slick mentioned that in addition to Alice in Wonderland her other inspiration for the song was "thebolero used by Miles Davis and Gil Evans on their 1960 album Sketches of Spain."  The song is essentially one long crescendo similar to that of Ravel's famous Boléro. The music combined with the song's lyrics strongly suggests the sensory distortions experienced withhallucinogens, and the song was later used in pop culture to imply or accompany just such a state.

I think this is a funny question since there are few songs I can think of with a more unsubtle message than “White Rabbit”. As many others have noted, it’s meaning is basically twofold: first, that your parents are shallow hypocrites who are too square to get the deeper implications of the stories they read you and who encourage the taking of boring drugs while condemning the cool ones and second, to go ahead and take those cool drugs. Message-wise, it’s of a piece with most of the band’s oeuvre. Hippies are today often stereotyped as insipid space cases with an aversion to conflict. But the default emotion of the Airplane, who in their heyday were considered to be counterculturists par excellence, was exactly the sort of in-your-face, self-righteous fury you hear in “White Rabbit”. I love Jefferson Airplane (one of the great things about the internet is being able to hear their concerts. Particularly in 1967 and ‘68, they were absolute psychedelic monsters), but I don’t like “White Rabbit” and never have. It’s not really a song—it’s more of a chant that builds to a climax that, when it comes, isn’t satisfying. Neither its generation gap snottiness nor it’s enthusiastically pro-drug message have aged well and musically it isn’t interesting. But there’s no doubt that it’s had both impact and staying power. There’s barely a TV show, movie or documentary made about the 60s in the last 50 years that doesn’t feature either it or its companion JA hit, “Somebody To Love”, somewhere in the soundtrack. It’s interesting that both those songs, which together are pretty much the only thing people under 50 know about the once-mighty Airplane, originated in Grace Slick’s first band, The Great Society. In my opinion, Jefferson Airplane’s original songs were pretty bad, or at least not very memorable. “The House at Pooneil Corner” and “Crown of Creation” have their charms, but catchiness isn’t among them. The Great Society, on the other hand, had a bunch of great songs. Pull up their 1966 live recording “Conspicuous Only In Its Absence” on YouTube and just listen to “Grimly Forming” or “Didn’t Think So”, along with the original versions of the biggies. If you want a song about doing acid, “Often As I May” beats “White Rabbit” in my book every time.
